text: has accused britain of not being serious
about dealing with the migrant crisis
involving the two countries he's been
speaking two days after 27 people
drowned trying to reach the uk mr macron
confirmed that european interior
ministers will meet on sunday but
without their british counterpart pretty
patel france withdrew its invitation to
pretty patel after boris johnson
released a letter outlining steps he
wanted france to take to prevent
crossings well let's get the very latest
from my colleague ben boulos who is
following all the developments for us in
dover ben over to you
yes and how different the situation is
politically from just 24 hours ago i was
standing here yesterday talking about
how there was a spirit of cooperation
between the uk and french governments
talk of joint action a unity of purpose
in trying to deter people from making
that perilous crossing from france to
the uk in small boats and also to tackle
the problem of the people smugglers the
human traffickers making vast sums as
they packed people into overcrowded
boats in some cases as we saw on
wednesday sending them ultimately to
their deaths
last night the uk prime minister boris
johnson published an open letter to the
french president emmanuel macron setting
out a number of points which he believed
were essential to tackling the problem
among them patrols joint patrols on
french beaches air
surveillance using technologies such as
sensors and radars and crucially
getting france to agree to a deal to
accept the return of people who had made
the crossing back to deter others from
trying to do the same that has angered
the french government so much so that
the invitation to the uk home secretary
to attend talks on sunday has now been
revoked a little earlier president
macron explained why he felt boris
johnson's letter was so misplaced
i am surprised by methods that aren't
serious we do not communicate from one
leader to another by tweets and letters
on these issues we don't throw warnings
around
come on
come on so ministers will work seriously
to deal with a serious issue with
serious people
that's why on sunday minister dominar
will meet with his counterparts from the
european union and the commission to
work on this issue and then we'll see
how we can work with the british on how
to respond effectively if they decide to
be serious
our europe correspondent jessica parker
is in calais and she told me that while
the uk has been frozen out the talks
will still go ahead with france and
other eu countries
pretty patel the uk home secretary
uh will not be there or that's currently
the situation we'll have to see how
things develop over the next couple of
days but you're right germany uh the
netherlands belgium european commission
ministers from those countries will come
here to discuss the issue and i think
this is part of a french push to really
try and point out that from their view
this is a shared european
problem why well some of the people who
end up here on the coast of northern
france and then try and make that
incredibly dangerous journey
across the channel they'll have entered
the eu
by another country so that's why
president emmanuel macron the french
president has talked about the need to
also
reinforce support for the european
union's
external borders so that discussion will
go on and involving as well importantly
i think the european commission who want
to have a role in trying to coordinate
any efforts because of course this is
all part of
a wider migration crisis that takes many
different forms and uh brings various
complications but of course we've also
seen
a huge issues very different set of
circumstances though on the poland
belarus border as well so i think there
is increasingly on the agenda this uh
issue of migration which has been an
issue now for a long time and of course
uh the problems that have been here uh
are not new but we saw a particularly
tragic day on wednesday when at least 27
people lost their lives a couple of days
on though now it seems all that talk of
joint cooperation at least between
britain and france seems to be crumbling
parker there for us in calais well let's
get the perspective in westminster we
can speak to our political correspondent
irony wells irony has there been any
reaction from the uk government to that
decision to revoke the invitation to the
uk home secretary patel uh for attending
the talks
that's right there has been lots of
reaction this morning from the uk
government both from the transport
secretary grant shaps who's been out and
about this morning responding to this
but also from downing street themselves
now grant shaps has stressed that he
would like to see more cooperation that
he would like to see that invitation to
the home secretary pretty patel
reinstated and the general view from the
uk government is that they believe in
some kind of cooperation is necessary to
try and resolve this problem downing
street have said they wanted explained
why this invitation to pretty patel has
suddenly been
revoked and that the priority should be
saving lives now the uk government have
also stressed that the solutions or
ideas that boris johnson set out in his
letter uh which has sparked this
controversy are ideas that have been put
forward before but that is kind of at
the crux of what the problem is here
because the french have argued in
particular that sort of by writing this
letter with the suggestions that france
should be taking back migrants who have
made that dangerous channel crossing
they are putting france in a difficult
situation because these are ideas that
have been put forward to france before
in private there are ideas that have
previously been rejected and france feel
that by kind of uh this now playing out
in a very public way with this open
letter by the prime minister but also
through tweets uh they're put in a
difficult position and they feel in a
way like this is kind of
putting pressure on them uh but also
that this is potentially kind of
politicizing the events that we've seen
over the last couple of days so i think
what has kind of originally started as
this tragic humanitarian crisis now also
bubbling into what is swiftly becoming a
quite public diplomatic row about this
